case_name: State of Assam vs. Krishna Rao and State of Assam vs. M. D. Bajid

facts.text: Criminal Appeal Nos. 92 and 93 of 1970 filed by State of Assam.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal Nos. 92 93 of 1970. Appeals by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeals by special leave from judgment and order dated April 30, 1969 of Assam Nagaland High Court in Cr. As. Nos. 61 and 62 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 30, 1969 of the Assam Nagaland High Court at Gauhati in Cr. As. Nos. 61 62 of 1968.

facts.text: High Court allowed appeals by respondents Krishna Rao and M.D. Bajid against Special Judge judgments dated June 12, 1968.

anchor.surface_text: under Art. 136 of the Constitution are directed against the companymon judgment of the Assam Nagaland High Court dated April 30, 1969,allowing two appeals by the two respondents  Crl. A. 61 of 1968 M. D. 24 0 Bajid vs. State of Assam and Crl. A. 62 of 1968 V. Krishna Rao vs. The State of Assam  against two separate judgments of the Special Judge, Gauhati dated June 12, 1968

facts.text: Krishna Rao was Garrison Engineer, MES at Jorhat.

anchor.surface_text: Accused Krishna Rao was a Garrison Engineer, MES at Jorhat and M. D. Bajid  appellant in the other case  was the Assistant Garrison Engineer under him.

facts.text: M.D. Bajid was Assistant Garrison Engineer under Krishna Rao.

anchor.surface_text: Accused Krishna Rao was a Garrison Engineer, MES at Jorhat and M. D. Bajid  appellant in the other case  was the Assistant Garrison Engineer under him.

facts.text: Messrs Barakar Engineering and Foundry Works, Calcutta were contractors under MES Jorhat for supplying fabricated building materials.

anchor.surface_text: During the term of office of these two officers, it is alleged that Messrs Barakar Engineering and Foundry Works, Calcutta were companytractors under the MES, Jorhat for supplying fabricated building materials and for raising structures with that material at the sites selected by the MES.

facts.text: Chief Engineer, Eastern Command entered into the contract.

anchor.surface_text: The Chief Engi- neer, Eastern Command, it is number disputed, is the person who entered into the companytract and after the companytract was accepted the accused Krishna Rao

facts.text: Krishna Rao was in overall charge of execution of the contract.

anchor.surface_text: the accused Krishna Rao in the capacity of Garrison Engineer was in overall charge of the execution of that companytract and NY. D. Bajid was his Assistant.

facts.text: Contractor entitled to 75% of value of goods supplied through running account bills.

anchor.surface_text: According to the terms of the companytract the companytractor was entitled to receive 75 of the value of the goods supplied through running account bills.

facts.text: Payments vetted first by Bajid as Assistant Garrison Engineer.

anchor.surface_text: These payments had to be be vetted in the first instance by Bajid as Assistant Garrison Engi- neer.

facts.text: Two running bills paid up to May 21, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: For the goods already supplied two running bills were submitted and the. payments under those bills were made upto May 21, 1964.

facts.text: On August 13, 1964, Krishna Rao caught accepting Rs. 10,000 bribe from C.L. Noronha.

anchor.surface_text: with the result that on August 13, 1964 first Krishna Rao was caught accepting a bribe of Rs. 10,000 from Noronha and thereafter Bajid was caught when he received Rs. 5,000 as bribe from the same individual in a similar manner.

facts.text: On August 13, 1964, Bajid caught receiving Rs. 5,000 bribe from C.L. Noronha.

anchor.surface_text: with the result that on August 13, 1964 first Krishna Rao was caught accepting a bribe of Rs. 10,000 from Noronha and thereafter Bajid was caught when he received Rs. 5,000 as bribe from the same individual in a similar manner.

facts.text: C.L. Noronha filed written complaint Ex.1 on August 11, 1964 to police officers Kapur and Bishnoi.

anchor.surface_text: On August 11, 1964 he accordingly went to the office of the Superintendent of Police, S.P.W., Partk Street and narrated his companyplaint to the S. P. Mr. Choudhury. ... P.W. 3 thereupon filed his written companyplaint Ex. 1 with these officers,

facts.text: Trap laid; on August 13, 1964 at 1:40 p.m. Rao arrived and accepted Rs.10,000.

anchor.surface_text: At about 1.40 p.m. Rao, accused, arrived in the office. Thereafter what happened had better be stated in the words of P.W. 3 himself, I greeted him hello Mr. Krishna Rao, companye in, companye in, as he took his seat I closed the front door for privacys sake. ... He picked up the bundle of numberes, fiddled with the same for a while and kept the same in his trousers right hand pocket.

facts.text: Raiding party recovered Rs.10,000 GC notes from Rao's right pant pocket.

anchor.surface_text: From the right hand side of the pant pocket of Shri Krishna Rao Mr. Kapur took out the bundle of 100 rupee G.C. numberes.

facts.text: Notes smeared with phenolphthalein powder.

anchor.surface_text: After P.W. 3 was searched the currency numberes were besmeared with a white powder  phenol-phalein powder  and instruction was given that if anybody touched the numberes, then, when his fingers were dipped in water, that water would turn reddish.

facts.text: Special Judge convicted Krishna Rao on June 12, 1968 under s.161 IPC and s.5(2) r/w 5(1)(d) PC Act, sentenced to 1 year RI and fine.

anchor.surface_text: Believing the prosecution evidence the companyrt companyvicted accused Rao and sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for one year on each companynt under s. 161. I.P.C. and s. 5  2  read with s. 5  1   d  of the Prevention of Corruption Act and also to fine of Rs. 1,000

facts.text: Special Judge convicted Bajid similarly, sentenced to 1 year RI and Rs.500 fine.

anchor.surface_text: Like Rao he was also sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for one year on each companynt under s. 161, 1. P.C. and under s. 5  2  read with s. 5   1    d  of the Prevention of Corruption Act. He was also sentenced to fine of Rs. 500

facts.text: High Court acquitted both accused on April 30, 1969.

anchor.surface_text: For all these reasons the High Court acquitted Rao. Bajid was also acquitted, broadly speaking, for similar reasons.

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside High Court judgment and restores Special Judge's convictions.

anchor.surface_text: For the foregoing reasons, in our opinion, these appeals must succeed and allowing the same we set aside the judgment of the High Court and restore those of the Special Judge.

facts.text: On August 13, 1964 around 4 p.m., Bajid accepted Rs.5,000 from Noronha.

anchor.surface_text: Round about 4 Oclock Mr. Bajid entered my room. ... Mr. Bajid took the bundle in his hand and put the same in the right hand pocket of his pant.

facts.text: Raiding party recovered Rs.5,000 from Bajid's right pant pocket.

anchor.surface_text: A bundle of C. numberes was recovered from the right hand pocket of pant of Mr. Bajid by Mr. Kapur.

issues.text: Whether the independent witnesses Chaliha and Barua could see and hear the transaction of bribe acceptance through the peepholes, and whether the High Court rightly entertained doubts about the peepholes.

anchor.surface_text: the learned single Judge of the High Court at the outset referred to the English decision in Brannan v. Peek 1  and to the decision of this Court in Rao S. B. Singh Anr. v. State of Vindhya Pradesh  2   and observed that in trap cases the matter has to be looked into with great circumspection. In the light of this observation the High Court said that Noronhag evidence required corroboration by some independent witnesses.

issues.text: Whether the presumption under Section 4 of the Prevention of Corruption Act arises upon proof that the accused accepted or obtained gratification other than legal remuneration, merely from recovery of tainted currency notes.

anchor.surface_text: by virtue of s. 4 of the Prevention of Corruption Act the Courts were legally obliged to raise the presumption that the two accused had accepted or obtained or agreed to accept or attempted to obtain that money

issues.text: Whether the omission to conduct the phenolphthalein test on the accused's hands and other minor discrepancies vitiate the prosecution evidence in the trap cases.

anchor.surface_text: Finally, the omission of the prosecution to dip Raos hands in water to see whether it had changed its colour on account of the application of phenolphalein powder was also considered by the High Court to be a highly important circumstance rendering the prosecution version unacceptable.

issues.text: Whether Bajid's trial was vitiated due to non-supply of copies of witness statements from Krishna Rao's case, causing prejudice to his defence.

anchor.surface_text: We may now turn to the question whether omission to supply to Bajid copies of the statements made by the witnesses in Raos case has prejudiced Bajids defence.

issues.text: Whether the sanction to prosecute under Section 6 of the Prevention of Corruption Act was valid.

anchor.surface_text: An objection was also raised in the trial court about the legality of the sanction to prosecute the two accused persons but the court considered Ex. 40

arguments.claim: Prosecution evidence regarding existence of peepholes and witnesses seeing the passing of money is trustworthy and should be accepted

anchor.surface_text: Before us on behalf of the State of Assam it has been strongly contended that the prosecution evidence with regard to the existence of the peepholes and the eye-witnesses having seen the actual passing of money through them is trustworthy and should be accepted.

arguments.court_reasoning: Minor discrepancies in peepholes indicate truth; raid party timing shows they witnessed passing; no suggestion of informant

arguments.claim: Direct evidence of passing money wrongly brushed aside due to omission of phenolphthalein test on Rao's hands, which is immaterial given direct evidence

anchor.surface_text: This direct evidence, it is argued, has been wrongly brushed aside, on the ground of omission to carry out the phenolphthalein test in the case of Rao which, in view of direct evidence of passing of money, was wholly immaterial

arguments.court_reasoning: Omission immaterial with direct evidence and recovery

arguments.claim: High Court erred in discrediting peephole testimony for slender reasons and ignoring vital considerations

anchor.surface_text: and on account of inconsequential circumstances in the case of Bajid. The High Court, it is contended, has erred seriously in discrediting the testimony with regards to the peepholes for reasons which are too slender to bear scrutiny

arguments.court_reasoning: Reasons too slender; minor variations normal and indicate truth

arguments.claim: Once recovery of money accepted, presumption under s.4 Prevention of Corruption Act arises obligatorily

anchor.surface_text: In any event when the evidence of the recovery of money from the pockets of the pants of both the accused persons has been accepted and upheld by both the courts, then, by virtue of s. 4 of the Prevention of Corruption Act

court_response_anchor.surface_text: nadequate. Notwithstanding anything companytained in sub-section  1  and  2  the companyrt may decline to draw the presumption referred to in either o

arguments.court_reasoning: Presumption arises on proof of acceptance/obtaining gratification other than legal remuneration; mandatory, rebuttable only by proof of high probability

arguments.claim: High Court wrongly declined presumption requiring proof of receipt with guilty conscience first

anchor.surface_text: the Courts were legally obliged to raise the presumption that the two accused had accepted or obtained or agreed to accept or attempted to obtain that money as a motive or reward such as is mentioned in S. 161, P.C. unless the contrary was proved.

arguments.court_reasoning: Erroneous view; cites State of Madras v A Vaidianatha Iyer, Emden, Dhanvantrai etc.; gratification literal meaning, no need for prior proof of bribe

arguments.claim: Peepholes not mentioned prior to incident; sizes differ; who/ how made inconsistent; tools not seized; door material disputed

anchor.surface_text: After referring to the evidence with regard to the peepholes the High Court felt some doubts about the boring of peepholes prior to the occurrence as alleged. In entertaining the doubt... principally influenced by the following factors In Ex. 2... no reference to peepholes

arguments.court_reasoning: Minor discrepancies normal, indicate truth not falsehood

arguments.claim: Chaliha could not see entire transaction through small peephole

anchor.surface_text: the High Court also entertained some doubt about the version that Chaliha could with one eye peep through the lower hole of small dimension and see the entire transaction.

arguments.court_reasoning: Minor variations inconsequential

arguments.claim: Improper to use government servants as trap witnesses; not truly independent

anchor.surface_text: While expressing this doubt the High Court added that it was improper to take the help of Government servants in such matters. Being interested in the success of the trap these witnesses... could not be considered to be so independent

arguments.claim: No corroboration that witnesses heard conversation between Noronha and Rao

anchor.surface_text: The High Court further entertained reasonable doubt whether Chaliha and Barua could have heard the conversation between Noronha and Rao.

arguments.court_reasoning: Witnesses corroborated Noronha fully

arguments.claim: No corroborative evidence for assurance of payment of bribe re second RAR bill

anchor.surface_text: The High Court further felt that there was no corroborative evidence regarding assurance of payment of bribe in regard to the payment -If the second R.A.R.

arguments.claim: Delay in bills due to red-tapism, not for extracting bribe

anchor.surface_text: Indeed. the High Court did not feel impressed by the evidence that the payment of the bills was delayed with the object of getting bribe. The delay of three months... due to red-tapism

arguments.claim: Recovery alone insufficient without independent corroboration of acceptance; requires proof of guilty mind

anchor.surface_text: there being no independent corroboration of the acceptance of the bribe the mere possession and recovery... was not sufficient to show that this was the money which had been received by him within the meaning of s. 161, I.P.C.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: nadequate. Notwithstanding anything companytained in sub-section  1  and  2  the companyrt may decline to draw the presumption referred to in either o

arguments.court_reasoning: Presumption arises from recovery/proof of obtaining; no prior guilty mind needed

arguments.claim: Defence version not ruled out as prosecution showed no evidence of vehicle used by Rao

anchor.surface_text: In regard to the defence evidence the High Court felt that the defence version could not be ruled out because the prosecution had not led any evidence to show as to, by which vehicle Rao had come

arguments.court_reasoning: Defence thrust version wholly improbable and flimsy

arguments.claim: Noronha failed to inform superiors about Rao's conduct

anchor.surface_text: The High Court also criticised Noronhas failure to inform his superior officers about Raos conduct.

arguments.claim: Omission to conduct phenolphthalein test on Rao's hands renders prosecution unacceptable

anchor.surface_text: Finally, the omission of the prosecution to dip Raos hands in water to see whether it had changed its colour on account of the application of phenolphalein powder was also considered... highly important circumstance

arguments.court_reasoning: Wholly immaterial given direct evidence

arguments.claim: Chaliha did not see Bajid receive money

anchor.surface_text: Bajid was also acquitted... with the additional circumstances i that according to Chalihas statement he had not seen from the peepholes whether Bajid had received the money

arguments.court_reasoning: Chaliha saw Bajid take money and put in pocket; cross-exam distinction minor

arguments.claim: Non-supply of copies of witness statements from Rao's case prejudiced Bajid's defence; taints trial

anchor.surface_text: ii that the copies of depositions of witnesses in Raos case had not been supplied to Bajid for facilitating their cross- examination and this... had prejudiced Bajid to a great extent... entire trial... tainted

arguments.court_reasoning: No law requires copies from separate trial; could inspect/copy record

arguments.claim: Bajid decoyed to office; defence probable

anchor.surface_text: The High Court further expressed its opinion that Bajid had been decoyed to the place of occurrence and. therefore, the defence version... was held to be highly probable.

arguments.court_reasoning: Defence version improbable; raid timing inconsistent with decoying without witness

arguments.claim: Money thrust into pocket by Noronha; no demand or acceptance

anchor.surface_text: Accused Krishna Rao in his statement under s. 342... It is not correct... Noronha... pushed something my right hand pocket. Then Mr. Bishnoi came and Mr. Kapur brought out the bundle

arguments.court_reasoning: Wholly unsatisfactory, unreasonable, flimsy

arguments.claim: Went to office for store inspection, not bribe

anchor.surface_text: On 13-8-1964 just at about 1-30 p.m. I was taken to the site office godown by Shri Srivastava and Shri Chatterjee... for inspection of stores.

arguments.court_reasoning: No prosecution evidence on vehicle does not make defence probable; overall improbable

arguments.claim: Similar defence for Bajid: money thrust, no demand

anchor.surface_text: In answer to question No. 7 he said The fact is that as soon as I entered the room Mr. Noronha bolted the room from inside and he pulled out something... pushed the same into my pant pocket.

arguments.court_reasoning: Same as Rao; improbable

arguments.claim: Independent witnesses Chaliha and Barua reliable; saw and heard transaction; accused dumbfounded

anchor.surface_text: The learned Special Judge considered the two prosecution witnesses, Chaliha and Barua, as independent witnesses having no animosity... They have also deposed that when caught the accused became, dumb-founded

arguments.court_reasoning: Trustworthy; corroborated

arguments.claim: Sanction to prosecute proper

anchor.surface_text: An objection was also raised in the trial court about the legality of the sanction to prosecute the two accused persons but the court considered Ex. 40, read in the light of the evidence of P.W. 4, to be proper sanction.

arguments.claim: In trap cases, evidence requires great circumspection and corroboration

anchor.surface_text: the learned single Judge of the High Court... referred to... Brannan v. Peek... and... Rao S. B. Singh... observed that in trap cases the matter has to be looked into with great circumspection.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: nysidered by the High Court to be a highly important circumstance rendering the prosecution version unacceptable. For all these reasons the High Court

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed need circumspection, but direct evidence + recovery sufficient; independent witnesses reliable

arguments.claim: Presumption u/s4 requires prior proof of acceptance with conscious/guilty mind

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, according to the appellants submission, has wrongly declined to raise this presumption on the ground that the factum of receipt of money with a conscious mind or guilty conscience is necessary

arguments.court_reasoning: Erroneous; presumption obligatory on proof of obtaining gratification other than legal rem; cites multiple SC precedents

arguments.claim: Defence explanations rebut presumption as plausible

anchor.surface_text: The words unless the contrary is proved... makes it clear that the presumption has to be rebutted by proof and not by a bare explanation which is merely plausible.

arguments.court_reasoning: Rebuttal requires proof establishing high degree of probability, not mere plausible explanation

holdings.text: The High Court took an erroneous view of Section 4 of the Prevention of Corruption Act; presumption arises where it is proved that accused accepted or obtained gratification other than legal remuneration, obligatory on court to raise it without prior proof of receipt with guilty mind.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there is merit in the appellants contention that the High Court has taken an erroneous view of s. 4 of the Prevention of Corruption Act. That section reads Presumption where public servant accepts gratification other than legal remuneration 4  1  Where in any trial of an offence punishable under section 161 or section 165 of the Indian Penal Code or of an offence referred to in clause  a  or clause  b  of sub-section  1  of section 5 of this Act punishable under sub-section  2  thereof,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cites precedents like State of Madras v. A. Vaidianatha Iyer, Emden v. State of UP, Dhanvantrai, Jhangan, S.N. Bose; literal meaning of gratification; mandatory presumption rebuttable only by proof of high probability.

holdings.text: Recovery of tainted money from accused pockets triggers Section 4 presumption as gratification other than legal remuneration; defence version of money being thrust does not rebut as it is wholly unsatisfactory and flimsy.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies precedents to facts of recovery; defence lacks high degree of probability required to rebut.

holdings.text: Prosecution evidence regarding peepholes and independent witnesses seeing/hearing bribe transaction is trustworthy; minor discrepancies in descriptions indicate truth, not falsehood.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Timing of raid party entry shows they witnessed passing; variations normal for untutored witnesses; no informant suggested.

holdings.text: Omission to conduct phenolphthalein test on accused's hands is immaterial in face of direct evidence of passing and recovery of tainted notes.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct eyewitness and recovery sufficient; test not essential.

holdings.text: Defence version that money was thrust into pockets by complainant is wholly improbable, unreasonable and flimsy.

anchor.surface_text: Once the defence version, that moneys were thrust into the pockets of the pants of the two accused persons which is suggestive of the innocence and ignorance of what had been thrust into their pockets is held to be improbable, as in our view it must be so held, then, the judgment of the High Court has to be reversed

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inconsistent with raid timing and accused behaviour; no evidence supports.

holdings.text: Chaliha's evidence corroborates seeing Bajid take money and put in pocket; High Court misread as not seeing receipt.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Cross-exam distinction minor; saw taking and pocketing.

holdings.text: No legal requirement to supply copies of witness statements from separate trial (Rao's case) to Bajid; no prejudice to defence as could inspect and copy record.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Separate trials; no violation of law or natural justice.

anchor.surface_text: An objection was also raised in the trial court about the legality of the sanction to prosecute the two accused persons but the court considered Ex. 40, read in the light of the evidence of P.W. 4, to be proper sanction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Trial court correctly considered documents and evidence; not disturbed.

holdings.text: State appeals succeed; High Court judgment set aside, Special Judge convictions under s.161 IPC and s.5(2) r/w s.5(1)(d) PC Act restored.

anchor.surface_text: For the foregoing reasons, in our opinion, these appeals must succeed and allowing the same we set aside the judgment of the High Court and restore those of the Special Judge.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative effect of above holdings reverses acquittal.

anchor.surface_text: The learned single Judge of the High Court at the outset referred to the English decision in Brannan v. Peek 1  and to the decision of this Court in Rao S. B. Singh Anr. v. State of Vindhya Pradesh  2   and observed that in trap cases the matter has to be looked into with great circumspection. In the light of this observation the High Court said that Noronhag evidence required companyroboration by some independent witnesses.

precedents.cited_proposition: in trap cases the matter has to be looked into with great circumspection

precedents.citation: Rao S. B. Singh Anr. v. State of Vindhya Pradesh 2 1954 S.C.R. 1098

anchor.surface_text: the English decision in Brannan v. Peek 1  and to the decision of this Court in Rao S. B. Singh Anr. v. State of Vindhya Pradesh  2   and observed that in trap cases the matter has to be looked into with great circumspection. In the light of this observation the High Court said that Noronhag evidence required companyroboration by some independent witnesses. As the prosecution claimed Chaliha and Barua to be independent witnesses

precedents.case_name: Rao SB Singh v State of Vindhya Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: in trap cases the matter has to be looked into with great circumspection

precedents.citation: State of Madras v. A. Vaidianatha Iyer 1 1958 S.C.R. 580

anchor.surface_text: In State of Madras v. A. Vaidianatha Iyer 1  after reproduc- ting the relevant provisions of S. 4 of the Prevention of Corruption Act this Court observed that where it is proved that a gratification has been accepted, the presumption under S. 4 of the Prevention of Corruption Act shall at once arise. It is a presumption of law and it is obligatory on the Court to raise it in every case brought under S. 4.

precedents.case_name: State of Madras v A Vaidianatha Iyer
precedents.cited_proposition: presumption under S.4 PCA arises where gratification accepted; obligatory to raise
precedents.cited_holding: where it is proved that a gratification has been accepted, the presumption under S. 4 of the Prevention of Corruption Act shall at once arise. It is a presumption of law and it is obligatory on the Court to raise it in every case brought under S. 4.

precedents.citation: C. I. Emden v. The State of U.P. 2 1960 2 S.C.R. 592

anchor.surface_text: In C. 1. Emden v. The State of U.P.  2  the appellant, who was working as a loco foreman was found to have accepted a sum of Rs. 375 from a railway companytractor. The appellants explanation was that he bad borrowed the amount as he was in need of money for meeting the expenses of the clothing of his children who were studying in school.

precedents.case_name: CI Emden v State of UP
precedents.cited_proposition: presumption under S.4 arises on receipt of amount other than legal remuneration; gratification not limited to bribe
precedents.cited_holding: such presumption arose when it was shown that the accused had received the stated amount and that the said amount was number legal remuneration. The word gratification in s. 4 1  was to be given its literal dictionary meaning of satisfaction of appetite or desire it companyld number be companystrued to mean money paid by way of bribe.

precedents.citation: Dhanvantrai v. State of Maharashtra 1 A.I.R. 1964 Sc. 5J5

anchor.surface_text: In Dhanvantrai v. State of Maharashtra 1  it was observed that in order to raise the presumption under S. 4 1  of Prevention of Corruption Act what the prosecution has to prove is that the accused person has received gratification other than legal, remuneration and when it is shown that he has received a certain sum of money which was number a legal remuneration, then, the, companydition prescribed by this section is satisfied and the presumption thereunder must be raised.

precedents.cited_proposition: presumption raised when accused received gratification other than legal remuneration
precedents.cited_holding: what the prosecution has to prove is that the accused person has received gratification other than legal, remuneration and when it is shown that he has received a certain sum of money which was number a legal remuneration, then, the, companydition prescribed by this section is satisfied and the presumption thereunder must be raised.

precedents.citation: Jhangan v. State of U.P. 2 1966 3 S.C.R. 736

anchor.surface_text: In Jhangan v. State of U.P.  2  the above decisions were approved and it was observed that mere receipt of money is sufficient to raise the presumption under s. 4  1  of the Prevention of Corruption Act.

precedents.cited_proposition: mere receipt of money sufficient to raise presumption under S.4(1) PCA

precedents.citation: S. N. Bose v. State of Bihar 3

anchor.surface_text: Recently in S. N. Bose v. State of Bihar 3  this Court reviewed the case law on the point and observed We next take up the question as to the scope of s. 4 of the Prevention of Corruption Act. As mentioned earlier, the appellant admits the fact that he received a sum of Rs. 5 from P.W. 4 on March 14, 1964.

precedents.case_name: SN Bose v State of Bihar
precedents.cited_proposition: scope of S.4 PCA presumption; reviewed prior cases; rebuttal by proof not mere plausible explanation
precedents.cited_holding: the presumption under s. 4 has to be rebutted by proof and number by bare explanation which may be merely plausible. The required proof need number be such as is expected for sustaining a criminal companyviction it need only establish a high degree of probability.

precedents.citation: C. I. Emden v. State of U.P. supra

anchor.surface_text: The Court then set out a passage from Emden  supra  which was followed in D. V. Desai  supra  and Jhangan  supra . The Court then dealt with the question of the onus on the accused for proving the companytrary and observed that, according to the well-settled view of this Court, the words unless the companytrary is proved mean that the presumption raised by S. 4 has to be rebutted by proof and number by bare explanation which may be merely plausible.

precedents.case_name: CI Emden v State of UP
precedents.cited_proposition: presumption under S.4 arises on shown receipt other than legal remuneration

followed in D. V. Desai  supra  and Jhangan  supra . anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there is merit in the appellants contention that the High Court has taken an erroneous view of s. 4 of the Prevention of Corruption Act. That section reads Presumption where public servant accepts gratification other than legal remuneration 4  1  Where in any trial of an offence punishable under section 161 or section 165 of the Indian Penal Code or of an offence referred to in clause  a  or clause  b  of sub-section  1  of section 5 of this Act punishable under sub-section  2  thereof,

For the foregoing reasons, in our opinion, these appeals must succeed and allowing the same we set aside the judgment of the High Court and restore those of the Special Judge. The respondents, if on bail, must surrender to their bail bonds to serve out their sentences.
